course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Understanding Our Economy
course.description: This course introduces students to the fundamental principles of economics, in particular the determination of macroeconomic variables – output, employment, and prices – and the policy tools (and choices) used to (try to) achieve particular outcomes, over different time horizons. Special attention is being paid to current economic events in Hong Kong and globally.
course.prerequisites: a passing letter grade in LANG 1401 OR LANG 1402 OR LANG 1403 OR LANG 1404 OR LANG 1002 (prior to 2022-23)
course.exclusions: ECON 2123, ECON 3123, SOSC 1440

reviews.author: az
reviews.comment_content:
See previous posts.
Basically tightly following Principle of Macroeconomics by Frank, Robert H. and Ben S. Bernanke (8th ed) Chapters 1-15, 17. (Two thirds of this part is covered in DSE Econ.)
Plus two movies (Inside Job and Capital in 21st century), which will be examined in the final exam.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The normal rundown of a lecture is going through an assignment > apply concepts taught to analyze a newspaper article > developing the ideas of a new chapter using pen and paper > going through the powerpoint slides of that chapter.
The professor is capable of explaining concepts quite clearly, though sometimes going a bit fast as he is doing so many things in one lecture, so an important part of learning is doing the assignments.
reviews.comment_grading:
No comments on the grading. See the others for the statistics.

Midterm is 70 MCs in approximately one hour, and you will be tested on the mini-assignment contents as well.
Final is 86 MCs + 14 marks short question + 20 marks essay.
MCs include mini-assignment contents as well, and the 20 marks essay is based on the two movies (1 question for each movie and only need to choose one question to answer).
You also need to remember statistics from mini-assignments and lectures (e.g. US, China, HK GDP).
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload depends on whether you will do the assignments seriously.
There are one (regular) assignment (textbook questions/questions related to movie) and one mini-assignment (questions related to extra reading: can be book chapter, newspaper article or HK statistics/textbook questions) every week. Regular assignments are released on Thursday and due on next Tuesday, and mini-assignments are released on Tuesday and due on Thursday (so only 2 days time).
You can get full points for submitting anything for the assignments so there is little workload if you just want a pass. But since the contents in the mini-assignments will be examined, and doing the regular assignments can help you clear your concepts, you will eventually need to finish basically every assignment + mini-assignment if you want to do well in the exams, which will lead to a quite heavy workload.

reviews.author: dm
reviews.title: Expect to be at a disadvantage without HKDSE economics background
reviews.comment_content:
I think this course is very similar to SOSC1440, but this one is for 30CC intakes, we even have exams and shared materials together.

First introduce basic economic concepts like marginals, opportunity costs, sunk costs, demand-supply.

The macroeconomics part
GDP calculations,
CPI,
Labor market,
Unemployment,
Savings,
Money supply,
Bonds,
Planned Aggregate Expenditures,
Aggregate supply & demand
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is a nice gentlemen, polite and respectful
But i feel like the lecture time is poorly planned
He will spent a lot of time in explaining assignments/mini assignments, and have to rush the regular lecture content.

He likes to put everything from a chapter on a paper, encouraging us not to read the ppt from the book publisher. But i find his paper oversimplified many concepts, so I went back to the ppt eventually.

Its like two polars, his one paper is oversimplified, but the ppt is overcomplicated, so find a balance yourself and selectively skip the ppt.
reviews.comment_grading:
NO attendance
Assignments 24%
Mini-assignments 8%
midterm 26%
final 42%

Each assignments is 3% and Mini-assignments is 1%
There will be about 10-11 of them, only the best 8 will be counted.

Very generous grading, I get A- for around UQ.
reviews.comment_workload:
Going into this course, please expect everyone to have HKDSE economics background. All the content in this course is taught in HKDSE Econ.

Very heavy assignments workload, but graded by effort. As long as you submit you get the score.
Assignment is due every tuesday before class
Mini Assignment is due every thursday before class
There are assignments every week and mini-assignments nearly every week. I feel like i am haunted by this course as i have to submit things every few days.

Remember not to skip the readings / movie appreciation sessions, contents will be tested in final.
